abstract:
This text discusses the risks associated with harmful algal blooms (HABs) caused by toxin-producing cyanobacteria, specifically Microcystis, Dolichospermum, Aphanizomenon, and Pseudoanabaena species. These blooms can release toxins, called cyanotoxins, which can harm both human contact recreation and aquatic life if their concentration reaches certain thresholds. The California Cyanobacterial and Harmful Algal Bloom Network (CCHAB) provides guidance for responding to HABs based on toxin concentrations.

Two methods are mentioned for analyzing cyanotoxins: Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) and Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry/Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS/MS). ELISA is a cost-effective screening method that can quantify groups of congeners, or chemical variants, of cyanotoxins that share common structures. It uses antibody assays to detect the presence and quantity of specific toxins like microcystin, anatoxin-a, and cylindrospermopsin.

However, ELISA may not be able to quantify specific congeners at lower concentrations. In contrast, LC-MS/MS is a more advanced analytical method capable of accurately identifying and measuring individual cyanotoxin congeners at lower concentrations. It utilizes mass spectrometry to separate, identify, and quantify individual components present in the sample.

The necessity of these methods lies in their ability to help environmental and public health managers assess cyanotoxin risks accurately and effectively. By choosing the appropriate method based on the specific information required, they can make informed decisions regarding water safety and potential hazards for both human contact recreation and aquatic life.

Specifically mentioned are Microcystis, Dolichospermum, Aphanizomenon, and Pseudoanabaena species, which can reach dangerously high densities in the water column (13-25 g/L or above). The California Cyanobacterial and Harmful Algal Bloom Network (CCHAB) provides guidance to manage potential risks to human contact recreation and aquatic life, with action levels for commonly observed cyanotoxins listed in Table 1. These include Microcystin, Anatoxin-a, and Cylindrospermopsin.

Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is mentioned as a method for quantifying these cyanotoxins at concentrations relevant to the CCHAB action levels. ELISA can detect common chemical structures shared among different congeners, such as the ADDA amino acid side chain in microcystin congeners. Specific ELISA antibody assays are available for quantification of anatoxin-a, saxitoxins, and cylindrospermopsins as well.

The text also mentions Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry/Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) as a more sensitive method capable of quantifying specific chemical congeners at lower concentrations, such as those described in USEPA Methods 544 and 545. When choosing a laboratory for cyanotoxin analysis, consider the need to measure single congeners or groups of congeners for each cyanotoxin, as different analytical methods have varying levels of sensitivity and specificity.
